H0.text: Electroluminescence is the process by which a vapor light produces visible light.

H1.text: Solutes are the process by which a vapor light produces visible light.

H2.text: Luminescent is the process by which a vapor light produces visible light.

H3.text: Solar Energy is the process by which a vapor light produces visible light.

A4.text: Electroluminescence is the result of radiative recombination of electrons and holes in a material, usually a semiconductor.

A5.text: Electroluminescent devices are fabricated using either organic or inorganic electroluminescent materials. The active materials are generally semiconductors of wide enough bandwidth to allow the exit of the light.

A6.text: A mercury-vapor lamp is a gas-discharge lamp that uses an electric arc through vaporized mercury to produce light.

A7.text: When power is applied, if there is sufficient voltage to ionize the argon, the ionized argon gas will strike a small arc between the starting electrode and the adjacent main electrode.

A8.text: Electroluminescence, a result of an electric current passed through a substance

A9.text: Light-emitting diodes (LEDs) emit light via electro-luminescence
